22.text: when I wanted to reframe the way we use information,

26.text: the way we work together: I invented the World Wide Web.

32.text: I want to ask your help in a new reframing.

41.text: I wrote a memo suggesting the global hypertext system.

44.text: Nobody really did anything with it, pretty much.

47.text: But 18 months later -- this is how innovation happens --

51.text: 18 months later, my boss said I could do it on the side,

55.text: as a sort of a play project,

57.text: kick the tires of a new computer we'd got.

59.text: And so he gave me the time to code it up.

62.text: So I basically roughed out what HTML should look like:

70.text: the idea of URLs, these names for things

75.text: I wrote the code and put it out there.

81.text: I was frustrated -- I was working as a software engineer

85.text: in this huge, very exciting lab,

87.text: lots of people coming from all over the world.

89.text: They brought all sorts of different computers with them.

92.text: They had all sorts of different data formats,

95.text: all sorts, all kinds of documentation systems.

97.text: So that, in all that diversity,

100.text: if I wanted to figure out how to build something

102.text: out of a bit of this and a bit of this,

104.text: everything I looked into, I had to connect to some new machine,

108.text: I had to learn to run some new program,

110.text: I would find the information I wanted in some new data format.

119.text: The frustration was all this unlocked potential.

121.text: In fact, on all these discs there were documents.

124.text: So if you just imagined them all

127.text: being part of some big, virtual documentation system in the sky,

134.text: then life would be so much easier.

136.text: Well, once you've had an idea like that it kind of gets under your skin

140.text: and even if people don't read your memo --

142.text: actually he did, it was found after he died, his copy.

145.text: He had written, "Vague, but exciting," in pencil, in the corner.

150.text: But in general it was difficult -- it was really difficult to explain

156.text: It's difficult to explain to people now that it was difficult then.

158.text: But then -- OK, when TED started, there was no web

161.text: so things like "click" didn't have the same meaning.

164.text: I can show somebody a piece of hypertext,

166.text: a page which has got links,

168.text: and we click on the link and bing -- there'll be another hypertext page.

174.text: You know, we've seen that -- we've got things on hypertext on CD-ROMs.

177.text: What was difficult was to get them to imagine:

180.text: so, imagine that that link could have gone

184.text: to virtually any document you could imagine.

187.text: Alright, that is the leap that was very difficult for people to make.

193.text: So yeah, it was difficult to explain, but there was a grassroots movement.

197.text: And that is what has made it most fun.

201.text: That has been the most exciting thing,

203.text: not the technology, not the things people have done with it,

205.text: but actually the community, the spirit of all these people

209.text: That's what it was like then.

211.text: Do you know what? It's funny, but right now it's kind of like that again.

214.text: I asked everybody, more or less, to put their documents --

216.text: I said, "Could you put your documents on this web thing?"

223.text: It's been a blast, hasn't it?

225.text: I mean, it has been quite interesting

227.text: because we've found out that the things that happen with the web

229.text: really sort of blow us away.

231.text: They're much more than we'd originally imagined

233.text: when we put together the little, initial website

237.text: Now, I want you to put your data on the web.

240.text: Turns out that there is still huge unlocked potential.

244.text: There is still a huge frustration

246.text: that people have because we haven't got data on the web as data.

250.text: What do you mean, "data"? What's the difference -- documents, data?

255.text: More or less, you read them, you can follow links from them, and that's it.

258.text: Data -- you can do all kinds of stuff with a computer.

260.text: Who was here or has otherwise seen Hans Rosling's talk?

266.text: One of the great -- yes a lot of people have seen it --

270.text: one of the great TED Talks.

274.text: in which he showed, for various different countries, in various different colors --

279.text: he showed income levels on one axis

282.text: and he showed infant mortality, and he shot this thing animated through time.

285.text: So, he'd taken this data and made a presentation

289.text: which just shattered a lot of myths that people had

292.text: about the economics in the developing world.

296.text: He put up a slide a little bit like this.

298.text: It had underground all the data

300.text: OK, data is brown and boxy and boring,

303.text: and that's how we think of it, isn't it?

305.text: Because data you can't naturally use by itself

308.text: But in fact, data drives a huge amount of what happens in our lives

312.text: and it happens because somebody takes that data and does something with it.

315.text: In this case, Hans had put the data together

317.text: he had found from all kinds of United Nations websites and things.

324.text: combined it into something more interesting than the original pieces

327.text: and then he'd put it into this software,

332.text: which I think his son developed, originally,

339.text: of saying, "Look, it's really important to have a lot of data."

343.text: And I was happy to see that at the party last night

346.text: that he was still saying, very forcibly, "It's really important to have a lot of data."

350.text: So I want us now to think about

352.text: not just two pieces of data being connected, or six like he did,

356.text: but I want to think about a world where everybody has put data on the web

361.text: and so virtually everything you can imagine is on the web

363.text: and then calling that linked data.

365.text: The technology is linked data, and it's extremely simple.

367.text: If you want to put something on the web there are three rules:

371.text: first thing is that those HTTP names --

376.text: we're using them not just for documents now,

380.text: we're using them for things that the documents are about.

382.text: We're using them for people, we're using them for places,

384.text: we're using them for your products, we're using them for events.

388.text: All kinds of conceptual things, they have names now that start with HTTP.

392.text: Second rule, if I take one of these HTTP names and I look it up

397.text: and I do the web thing with it and I fetch the data

399.text: using the HTTP protocol from the web,

401.text: I will get back some data in a standard format

404.text: which is kind of useful data that somebody might like to know

409.text: about that thing, about that event.

411.text: Who's at the event? Whatever it is about that person,

413.text: where they were born, things like that.

415.text: So the second rule is I get important information back.

417.text: Third rule is that when I get back that information

421.text: it's not just got somebody's height and weight and when they were born,

430.text: This person was born in Berlin; Berlin is in Germany.

434.text: And when it has relationships, whenever it expresses a relationship

437.text: then the other thing that it's related to

440.text: is given one of those names that starts HTTP.

444.text: So, I can go ahead and look that thing up.

446.text: So I look up a person -- I can look up then the city where they were born; then

449.text: I can look up the region it's in, and the town it's in,

452.text: and the population of it, and so on.

455.text: So I can browse this stuff.

461.text: I wrote an article entitled "Linked Data" a couple of years ago

464.text: and soon after that, things started to happen.

468.text: The idea of linked data is that we get lots and lots and lots

472.text: of these boxes that Hans had,

474.text: and we get lots and lots and lots of things sprouting.

476.text: It's not just a whole lot of other plants.

479.text: It's not just a root supplying a plant,

481.text: but for each of those plants, whatever it is --

484.text: a presentation, an analysis, somebody's looking for patterns in the data --

487.text: they get to look at all the data

490.text: and they get it connected together,

492.text: and the really important thing about data

494.text: is the more things you have to connect together, the more powerful it is.

500.text: And, pretty soon Chris Bizer at the Freie Universitat in Berlin

504.text: who was one of the first people to put interesting things up,

508.text: you know Wikipedia, the online encyclopedia

511.text: with lots and lots of interesting documents in it.

513.text: Well, in those documents, there are little squares, little boxes.

517.text: And in most information boxes, there's data.

520.text: So he wrote a program to take the data, extract it from Wikipedia,

524.text: and put it into a blob of linked data

526.text: on the web, which he called dbpedia.

529.text: Dbpedia is represented by the blue blob in the middle of this slide

533.text: and if you actually go and look up Berlin,

535.text: you'll find that there are other blobs of data

537.text: which also have stuff about Berlin, and they're linked together.

540.text: So if you pull the data from dbpedia about Berlin,

543.text: you'll end up pulling up these other things as well.

545.text: And the exciting thing is it's starting to grow.

548.text: This is just the grassroots stuff again, OK?

550.text: Let's think about data for a bit.

553.text: Data comes in fact in lots and lots of different forms.

556.text: Think of the diversity of the web. It's a really important thing

559.text: that the web allows you to put all kinds of data up there.

562.text: So it is with data. I could talk about all kinds of data.

565.text: We could talk about government data, enterprise data is really important,

569.text: there's scientific data, there's personal data,

572.text: there's weather data, there's data about events,

574.text: there's data about talks, and there's news and there's all kinds of stuff.

578.text: I'm just going to mention a few of them

581.text: so that you get the idea of the diversity of it,

583.text: so that you also see how much unlocked potential.

589.text: Barack Obama said in a speech,

591.text: that he -- American government data would be available on the Internet

598.text: And I hope that they will put it up as linked data.

600.text: That's important. Why is it important?

602.text: Not just for transparency, yeah transparency in government is important,

605.text: but that data -- this is the data from all the government departments

608.text: Think about how much of that data is about how life is lived in America.

613.text: It's actual useful. It's got value.

615.text: I can use it in my company.

617.text: I could use it as a kid to do my homework.

619.text: So we're talking about making the place, making the world run better

624.text: In fact if you're responsible -- if you know about some data

628.text: in a government department, often you find that

630.text: these people, they're very tempted to keep it --

636.text: You hug your database, you don't want to let it go

638.text: until you've made a beautiful website for it.

640.text: Well, I'd like to suggest that rather --

644.text: who am I to say don't make a beautiful website?

646.text: Make a beautiful website, but first

656.text: OK, we have to ask for raw data now.

659.text: And I'm going to ask you to practice that, OK?

671.text: Practice that. It's important because you have no idea the number of excuses

675.text: people come up with to hang onto their data

677.text: and not give it to you, even though you've paid for it as a taxpayer.

681.text: And it's not just America. It's all over the world.

683.text: And it's not just governments, of course -- it's enterprises as well.

686.text: So I'm just going to mention a few other thoughts on data.

689.text: Here we are at TED, and all the time we are very conscious

694.text: of the huge challenges that human society has right now --

699.text: curing cancer, understanding the brain for Alzheimer's,

702.text: understanding the economy to make it a little bit more stable,

707.text: The people who are going to solve those -- the scientists --

709.text: they have half-formed ideas in their head,

711.text: they try to communicate those over the web.

714.text: But a lot of the state of knowledge of the human race at the moment

717.text: is on databases, often sitting in their computers,

723.text: In fact, I'll just go into one area --

726.text: if you're looking at Alzheimer's, for example,

728.text: drug discovery -- there is a whole lot of linked data which is just coming out

731.text: because scientists in that field realize

733.text: this is a great way of getting out of those silos,

736.text: because they had their genomics data in one database

740.text: in one building, and they had their protein data in another.

743.text: Now, they are sticking it onto -- linked data --

746.text: and now they can ask the sort of question, that you probably wouldn't ask,

751.text: What proteins are involved in signal transduction

753.text: and also related to pyramidal neurons?

755.text: Well, you take that mouthful and you put it into Google.

758.text: Of course, there's no page on the web which has answered that question

761.text: because nobody has asked that question before.

767.text: You ask the linked data -- which they've now put together --

770.text: 32 hits, each of which is a protein which has those properties

776.text: The power of being able to ask those questions, as a scientist --

779.text: questions which actually bridge across different disciplines --

781.text: is really a complete sea change.

786.text: Scientists are totally stymied at the moment --

788.text: the power of the data that other scientists have collected is locked up

793.text: and we need to get it unlocked so we can tackle those huge problems.

796.text: Now if I go on like this, you'll think that all the data comes from huge institutions

800.text: and has nothing to do with you.

805.text: In fact, data is about our lives.

807.text: You just -- you log on to your social networking site,

810.text: your favorite one, you say, "This is my friend."

815.text: You say, "This photograph, it's about -- it depicts this person. "

818.text: Bing! That's data. Data, data, data.

821.text: Every time you do things on the social networking site,

823.text: the social networking site is taking data and using it -- re-purposing it --

827.text: and using it to make other people's lives more interesting on the site.

831.text: But, when you go to another linked data site --

833.text: and let's say this is one about travel,

836.text: and you say, "I want to send this photo to all the people in that group,"

839.text: you can't get over the walls.

841.text: The Economist wrote an article about it, and lots of people have blogged about it --

844.text: The way to break down the silos is to get inter-operability

848.text: We need to do that with linked data.

850.text: One last type of data I'll talk about, maybe it's the most exciting.

853.text: Before I came down here, I looked it up on OpenStreetMap

856.text: The OpenStreetMap's a map, but it's also a Wiki.

858.text: Zoom in and that square thing is a theater -- which we're in right now --

861.text: The Terrace Theater. It didn't have a name on it.

863.text: So I could go into edit mode, I could select the theater,

865.text: I could add down at the bottom the name, and I could save it back.

870.text: And now if you go back to the OpenStreetMap. org,

873.text: and you find this place, you will find that The Terrace Theater has got a name.

878.text: I did that to the map. I just did that!

880.text: I put that up on there. Hey, you know what?

882.text: If I -- that street map is all about everybody doing their bit

885.text: and it creates an incredible resource

891.text: And that is what linked data is all about.

894.text: It's about people doing their bit

897.text: to produce a little bit, and it all connecting.

903.text: You do your bit. Everybody else does theirs.

907.text: You may not have lots of data which you have yourself to put on there

911.text: but you know to demand it.

920.text: I've only told you a very small number of things

923.text: There are data in every aspect of our lives,

925.text: every aspect of work and pleasure,

928.text: and it's not just about the number of places where data comes,

934.text: And when you connect data together, you get power

937.text: in a way that doesn't happen just with the web, with documents.

940.text: You get this really huge power out of it.

944.text: So, we're at the stage now

947.text: where we have to do this -- the people who think it's a great idea.

951.text: And all the people -- and I think there's a lot of people at TED who do things because --

954.text: even though there's not an immediate return on the investment

956.text: because it will only really pay off when everybody else has done it --

959.text: they'll do it because they're the sort of person who just does things

963.text: which would be good if everybody else did them.

966.text: OK, so it's called linked data.

968.text: I want you to make it.

970.text: I want you to demand it.

972.text: And I think it's an idea worth spreading.
